name: Kepler-394
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-394 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-394 is a star with 1.1839999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.13 times its radius. It is located 3560.61 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-394 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-394 b

Kepler-394 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.01 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-394.

The mass of Kepler-394 b is 2.99 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-394 b is 1.6 that of Earth. At 2.99 Earth masses, Kepler-394 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-394 c

Kepler-394 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.13 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-394.

The mass of Kepler-394 c is 3.24 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-394 c is 1.66 that of Earth. At 3.24 Earth masses, Kepler-394 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-394, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
